Message.Title: McDonald’s $8.25 Man and $8.75 Million CEO Shows Pay Gap
Message.Msg: Bloomberg: McDonald’s $8.25 Man and $8.75 Million CEO Shows Pay Gap By Leslie Patton - 2012-12-12T05:00:01Z I hate when my boss tells me she won’t give me a raise because she can smell me,” he said. Johnson, 44, needs the two paychecks to pay rent for his apartment at a single-room occupancy hotel on the city’s north side. While he’s worked at McDonald’s stores for two decades, he still doesn’t get 40 hours a week and makes $8.25 an hour, minimum wage in Illinois. Message.Title: It's Not Just The Surface
Message.Msg: For people who do not understand the new products and quite frankly it may be a little confusing. People are posting comments as if they are only counting Surface sales. Surface is just one physical device of the more than 100 available. HP, Sony, Dell, etc all make there own WIN 8 Device. It is not accurate and meaningless to base an investment on Surface Sales. I bought an Acer laptop with touchscreen and it runs the full version of Win8 and has a lighted keyboard that I needed. That means I can install any programs I want. I chose this machine because it is one of the most sturdy machines. That means I can tap the touch screen with no machine movement. I still want the Surface Pro simply to take in the car with it's unbelievable light weight and the magnetic keyboard works. So you do not have to wait for the Surface Pro to be able to install any program with Win8. The current Surface out is a WINRT. I will definitely take advantage and pick one of these up even though I have two new Win8 machines now. The reason is you get a free version of Microsoft Office with the $499.00 Surface RT. The cost of office is several hundred dollars. I need office and just need a machine to take in the car or while waiting for an appointment at the doctor etc. The $499.00 price is the current price. When it hits Staples and best buy that the price if the price is lower I would not want to miss the opportunity to get one of these. Supply is limited as they are making more now. Even though you cannot install programs on the WINRT surface the free version of office makes it a must if it goes on sale. Best Buy and Staples will cause a shortage of the Surface RT in my opinion. They ALWAYS ALWAYS have sales. So I will be watching the ads to get the quick for a SurfaceRT even though I have two other full featured brand New Windows 8 devices. You see Surface Pro does not come with the free version of office. It is a deal if it goes on sale! You have to feel it to enjoy it. Microsoft has not done the best job of advertising the pop up kiosk's. In Washington DC I called the Microsoft Store in Tysons Corner and they did not even know they had a popup kiosk in Columbia Mall in MD. There is no listing on the internet etc. So unless you are in the mall and see the kiosk you would not know they are selling Surfaces there. Everyone will know at Best Buy & Staples. Here comes the tidal wave.

Message.Title: Microsoft: 32% Upside Once Windows 8 Jitters Subside
Message.Msg: According to mot. fool,Interesting article: "Worldwide shipments of tablets are expected to be 122.3 million units currently, which means about 3.5 million of them are Windows 8 tablets based on the 2.9% figure mentioned above. By 2016, shipments are expected to reach 282.7 million units, and if Microsoft achieves the 10.3% market share that IDC predicts, their share of that is 29.1 million tablets running Windows 8. That is a 730% gain in the number of tablets using Microsoft’s OS within 4 years! "

Message.Title: Half Of REPUBLICANS Say Obama Has Mandate To Raise Taxes On Rich
Message.Msg: Obama Wins Almost 50% Republicans on Tax Mandate in Poll By Mike Dorning - Dec 11, 2012 7:00 PM CT. President Barack Obama won the public argument over taxes so decisively that almost half of Republicans now say he has an election mandate to raise rates on the rich. Majorities of about 2-to-1 also read the election results as an endorsement of Obama’s pledge to protect Social Security and Medicare benefits, according to a Bloomberg National Poll of 1,000 adults conducted Dec. 7-10.

It is simple, posting on a message board is nearly exactly impotent usage of ones time, might as well walk the street with a sign on your chest conveying your message. Put plainly anyone who had both intelligence and something to achieve would not be here 24/7

Message.Title: Republicans Deemed Too Pro-Rich, 57% in Poll Want Change
Message.Msg: Bloomberg By John McCormick - Dec 12, 2012 7:00 PM CT The majority of Americans say the Republican Party needs a major overhaul after electoral losses revealed demographic, messaging and technological shortfalls compared with Democrats, a Bloomberg National Poll shows. Even among Republicans, just 16 percent say their party is fine and doesn’t need to change. The survey also shows the party is viewed as too protective of the wealthy and that New Jersey Governor Chris Christie has a slight edge among high-profile Republicans who may lead the party. The survey also shows the party is viewed as too protective of the wealthy and that New Jersey Governor Chris Christie has a slight edge among high-profile Republicans who may lead the party out of the wilderness. Photographer: Andrew Burton/Getty Images The party is reassessing its positions and tactics after losing the presidential race, failing to make gains in the U.S. Senate and seeing their House majority shrink after the 2012 elections. The Republican National Committee this week created a study group to examine how it can improve the party’s performance ahead of the 2014 congressional elections and 2016 race for the White House.

Message.Title: Surface flops big time.
Message.Msg: “The Windows RT Surface barely registered, making up 0.13% of tablet web traffic. That means that out of every 10,000 tablet ad impressions, an average of 13 came from Surface.”

Message.Title: Another great strategy MSFT, Keep it going!
Message.Msg: “Pricing didn’t help. Surface starts at US$500, the same as the iPad… It’s as if Microsoft didn’t notice the Xooms, Playbooks, and Galaxy Tabs that had already failed with that strategy… There’s also the tablet itself. Its operating system is complicated, split into two desktop environments. It has a sparse app library. The device’s display, battery life, and cameras are inferior to the iPad’s. A kickstand and a keyboard clicking sound aren’t going to make up for that.”
